abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is satisfactory,
            sustainability likely, and the institutional development
            impact is substantial. Despite success, some lessons should
            be emphasized. Future financing of savings and credit
            associations by financial institutions should be linked to
            matching funds provided from the internal mobilization of
            savings, and resources of the Savings and Credit Association
            (SCA), so as to support the development of the SCA system.
            To this end, more than one financial intermediary would be
            preferable, where interested commercial banks that meet the
            agreed eligibility, should be permitted to participate in
            the project. However, capitalization should be established
            as a priority, before lending expansion, particularly for
            institutions like the Rural Finance Corporation (RFC) and
            SCAs, in order to mitigate lending risks. Consequently,
            lending norms should be based on the ability to minimize
            such risks, where loan limits should not be increased until
            such norms, and regulations are in place. It is also
            reinforced that stronger implementation coordination among
            the agencies involved - the Project Implementation Unit,
            RFC, and nongovernmental organizations - could have further
            increased project success, and contributed to lower costs.
            Similarly, stronger coordination among the large number of
            donor funds, could have ensured sustainability, reduced
            reliance on donor funds, and endured lower operational
            costs. Other lessons suggest training options, a fee-based
            technical assistance, strengthened regulatory capacity of
            the State Supervisory Body of SCAs, and precautionary
            financial clauses to adhere by, and phase out subsidies.

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Rural Finance
            Project is to develop and test a cooperative rural banking
            system that would efficiently provide financial services to
            small private farmers and rural entrepreneurs.   The project
            consists of four components.  The first component will
            provide technical assistance and training to develop Savings
            and Credit Associations (SCAs) in the rural areas of
            Moldova.  The second component is the establishment of
            regulatory body of the SCAs, which will provide technical
            assistance and training to the Rural Finance Project
            Implementation Unit to temporarily supervise and regulate
            SCAs, develop the framework for a permanent regulatory body
            of SCAs, and finance year-end audits of SCAs established
            under the project.  The third component is the establishment
            of the Rural Finance Corporation (RFC), which will operate
            according to agreed prudential rules and an agreed policy
            manual, specifying RFC's lending polices.  The fourth
            component will provide a credit line to RFC, who in turn
            will extend loans exclusively to SCAs operating in the rural areas.
